title: Ensure Permissions On /etc/cron.d Are Configured
overview: <paragraph>The /etc/cron.d directory contains system cron jobs that need to run in a similar manner to the hourly, daily weekly and monthly jobs from /etc/crontab, but require more granular control as to when they run. The files in this directory cannot be manipulated by the crontab command, but are instead edited by system administrators using a text editor. The commands below restrict read/write and search access to user and group root, preventing regular users from accessing this directory.</paragraph><paragraph></paragraph><paragraph>Granting write access to this directory for non-privileged users could provide them with the means for gaining unauthorized elevated privileges. Granting read access to this directory could give an unprivileged user insight in how to gain elevated privileges or circumvent auditing controls.</paragraph>
poc: <paragraph>File:	/etc/cron.d</paragraph><paragraph>the file's Other Execute to be set to false	true</paragraph><paragraph>the file's Group ID to be set to 0	0</paragraph><paragraph>the file's Group Execute to be set to false	true</paragraph><paragraph>the file's Other Read to be set to false	true</paragraph><paragraph>the file's Group Read to be set to false	true</paragraph><paragraph>the file's Group Write to be set to false	false</paragraph><paragraph>the file's Other Write to be set to false	false</paragraph><paragraph>the file's User ID to be set to 0	0</paragraph>
remediation: <paragraph>Run the following commands to set ownership and permissions on /etc/cron.d:</paragraph><paragraph></paragraph><paragraph># chown root:root /etc/cron.d</paragraph><paragraph># chmod og-rwx /etc/cron.d</paragraph>
